events.target_title: No way to know if the password is revealed or not

note.body:
I checked and there **is** a visual change: the *show/hide password* button is pressed or not.

Problem: the difference is very difficult to see, light grey VS less light grey:
![not pressed VS pressed](/uploads/42f3b575503f7705d0212e24903b3fc0/reveal_pwd_show_and_hide.png)

Possible solutions:

- use **darker grey** for pressed button state
- use **primary color** (blue with default Gnome theme) for pressed button state
- use a **different icon for the 2 states**: "opened eye" VS "closed eye" or "opened eye" VS "crossed eye" (but there is still the problem of the meaning of "opened eye" is it the state or the action that is performed when clicking ?)
- use a different control: a **switch** could be a good replacement... but it takes a lot of space (and it needs a label)
- use a different control but **move it to the header bar**: since seeing or not the password is a quite important action it could be moved to the header bar where we have more place to display a switch control (just like the ON/OFF wifi switch in Gnome settings)
- use a different control (a switch) but **move it to its own line**, just before the password line.

The 2 last propositions have an advantage: if ever one day we have 2 lines for password (as a failsafe) it would be useless to have a "button on the same line as the password". But this is another issue.

events.target_title: Re-enable "Automatically raise windows" feature in latest versions of Tweaks [ubuntu 18.10+]
Re-enable "Automatically raise windows" feature in latest versions of Tweaks [ubuntu 18.10+]

note.body:
Hi @jbicha, thanks for responding.

Possibly a misunderstanding (maybe on my part.):

Please correct me if I am mistaken, but I am under the assumption that "Automatically raise windows" expected behavior is to cause newly opened windows to raise and gain focus. 

**Recommended solution doesn't cover intended behavior**

The recommended solution (hover to focus, or right-click to focus) does not cover the intended use behavior.

*To rephrase the problem and hoped for solution:*

### **Issue:**

Newly opened windows in GNOME 3 are not focused. (they open in the background). 

This results in the intermediary step of having to click a popup notification "Application [__________] is ready." to cause the window to gain focus.

### **Desired behavior**

Newly opened windows should immediately raise and gain focus.

### **Expectation: (re. Gnome Tweaks setting)**

Setting (previously available) Automatically Raise Windows should produce the intended auto-raise behavior, without having to click/hover focus on the new window.

If I'm mistaken, or this is not the behavior, I hope you can point me in the right direction.

Thanks!

E.g. activate Emacs or Macos key schemas? Anyway, user must have an ability to redefine every keyboard shortcut, or create new one, so is there other method to do it?

events.target_title: Bind hotkeys with Super key didn't work in GTK3 apps

note.body:
Sorry, I don't understand. I see a lot of bindings in GTK source code. E.g. Ctrl+C for copying. So there must be ability to rewrite or disable it. If I can do it outside GTK (on WM or DE layer) - it's perfect, I will do. But I don't find such place, only inside GTK.

Your answer assume that there willn't be any bindings inside GTK code in future. But I'm sure it's not a true. If you have hardcoded bindings in some part of OS (e.g. in toolkit) - there must be interface to disable or rewrite it.

And in all cases it's not a toolkit or application task to decide which keys and key combinations user should and can use. Now you have css bindings, but they don't work as they should. So, it's a bug, of course.

Each application (and toolkit of course too!) must support all combinations, that are supported by OS. Especially, with Super. Super is a just 4th modification key, nothing more. If some OSes want to use it system-wide for some purposes, it doesn't mean that applications can't use it. Especially on Linux, where Super is just a key like control or alt. It's very comfortable to use Super+C for copying, but GTK don't allow me to do it (as I see - exactly GTK, not Gnome or Linux). But as you correctly told - it's not a toolkit task at all to decide which combination are used for common tasks, such as copying text.

note.body:
Hi Lillolollo, 
Yes, uninstalled 2.10.8, cleaned up remaining program and appdata files, etc.  I was able to Fix it by:
opening the start menu shortcut properties
changed the "Start in" location from %userprofile% to the specific user location "C:\users\myusername\"
That nearly fixed it.  It would work, and fail, randomly.
But this solved it!>> I then changed the "Start in location"![gimp_2.10.8_start_props](/uploads/5e835f3169aaeda65d0eb8a911e365c5/gimp_2.10.8_start_props.png) to blank.
GIMP now start properly every time.

I think it has something to do with windows permissions - installing requires admin password and running GIMP as admin causes files to be saved in admin profile, but at least it worked.  Clearing the start in folder solves the starting issue, while allowing me to save in the correct profile location.

- Bob

events.target_title: Regression in 3.33: No graphical interface: "Failed to initialize accelerated iGPU/dGPU framebuffer sharing: No matching EGL configs"

note.body:
My recent Debian Bulsseye bug-report https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=942418 is referring to this one.

Problem might be caused by cogl-change. Libmutter 3.30.1 at ubuntu-18.10 requires GL version 1.2., libmutter 3.34.0 requires GL version 2.1. N o driver is selected because of error "Unable to create a suitable EGL context" or "OpenGL 2.1 or better is required".

At my laptop I could circumvent the problem by adding   Environment="MESA_GL_VERSION_OVERRIDE=2.1" 
to  /lib/systemd/system/gnome-shell-wayland.service.

Attached the failing log including MUTTER backend-debug and some own debug-statements.[GK_syslog](/uploads/76fca1235b2816153230114d81091966/GK_syslog)

This gives:

It uses libGL.so.1
Without using the override, this library returns GL_VERSION: 1.4, as can be seen at the log attached before???

It uses libGLESv2.so

events.target_title: Regression in 3.33: No graphical interface: "Failed to initialize accelerated iGPU/dGPU framebuffer sharing: No matching EGL configs"

note.body:
Indeed this problem is solved by fixing a bug at function try_create_context at cogl/cogl/winsys/cogl-winsys-egl.c line 331.
Next code should be added to set eglBinAPI correct for OPENGL_ES:

  else

    eglBindAPI (EGL_OPENGL_ES_API);

Now GL_VERSION: OpenGL ES 2.0 is selected, using driver libGLESv2.so.

Still software rendering is done, I think. Glxinfo shows the same values as reported before.

Next lines are showed at the log:

Oct 29 19:30:16 debian gnome-shell[1015]: Require OpenGL version 2.1 or later.

Oct 29 19:30:16 debian gnome-shell[1015]: Failed to initialize glamor

Oct 29 19:30:16 debian gnome-shell[1015]: Failed to initialize glamor, falling back to sw

Oct 29 19:30:16 debian systemd[950]: Started GNOME Shell on Wayland.

note.body:
I tested code of hw/xwayland/xwayland-glamor-gbm.c as should be active after latest merge-request https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/xorg/xserver/merge_requests/324 .
This indeed forces OpenGL ES 2.0 and avoids the glamor errors at syslog.

Unfortunately I get another error at syslog:

Nov  8 14:12:32 debian gsd-xsettings[7065]: libGL error: Version 4 or later of flush extension not found

Nov  8 14:12:32 debian gsd-xsettings[7065]: libGL error: failed to load driver: i915

It looks like GLX still tries to use llvmpipe.
Programs like xterm and Firefox on Xwayland are not working.

events.target_title: Folder Matching doesn't work with Exchange IMAP

note.body:
To answer your question: the goa_account_1545054984_2 is an proper exchange account that is used by Evolution (which i'm using until I can use Geary again). It's the same account and server as `account_01` but the `goa_account_1545054984_2` is an exchange account and `account_01` is an imap account – i understood Geary only speaks imap. (?)

Of the two new errors, the first error on `account_01` seems to be an duplicate of #234. (?)

It's an old script but it works on regular pictures but why not on large ones?
------------------------------------------------------

```
; The GIMP -- an image manipulation program
; Copyright (C) 1995 Spencer Kimball and Peter Mattis
;
; This program is free software; you can redistribute it and/or modify
; it under the terms of the GNU General Public License as published by
; the Free Software Foundation; either version 3 of the License, or
; (at your option) any later version.
; 
; This program is distributed in the hope that it will be useful,
; but WITHOUT ANY WARRANTY; without even the implied warranty of
; MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.  See the
; GNU General Public License for more details.
; 
; You should have received a copy of the GNU General Public License
; along with this program; if not, write to the Free Software
; Foundation, Inc., 675 Mass Ave, Cambridge, MA 02139, USA.
; http://www.gnu.org/licenses/gpl-3.0.html
;
; Copyright (C) 2008 elsamuko <elsamuko@web.de>
;
; Version 0.1 - Simulate a high quality photo like these from the National Geographic
;               Thanks to Martin Egger <martin.egger@gmx.net> for the shadow revovery and the sharpen script
;

(define (elsamuko-national-geographic aimg adraw shadowopacity
                                      sharpness screenopacity
                                      overlayopacity localcontrast
                                      screenmask tint)
  (let* ((img (car (gimp-drawable-get-image adraw)))
         (owidth (car (gimp-image-width img)))
         (oheight (car (gimp-image-height img)))
         (overlaylayer 0)
         (overlaylayer2 0)
         (screenlayer 0)
         (contrastlayer 0)         
         (tmplayer1 0)         
         (tmplayer2 0)         
         (floatingsel 0)
         
         (CopyLayer (car (gimp-layer-copy adraw TRUE)))
         (ShadowLayer (car (gimp-layer-copy adraw TRUE)))         
         
         (MaskImage (car (gimp-image-duplicate aimg)))
         (MaskLayer (cadr (gimp-image-get-layers MaskImage)))
         (OrigLayer (cadr (gimp-image-get-layers aimg)))
         (HSVImage (car (plug-in-decompose TRUE aimg adraw "Value" TRUE)))
         (HSVLayer (cadr (gimp-image-get-layers HSVImage)))
         (SharpenLayer (car (gimp-layer-copy adraw TRUE)))
         )
    
    ;init
    (gimp-context-push)
    (gimp-image-undo-group-start img)
    (if (= (car (gimp-drawable-is-gray adraw )) TRUE)
        (gimp-image-convert-rgb img)
        )
    ;(gimp-context-set-foreground '(0 0 0))
    ;(gimp-context-set-background '(255 255 255))
    
    ;shadow recovery from here: http://registry.gimp.org/node/112
    (if(> shadowopacity 0)
       (begin
         (gimp-image-add-layer img CopyLayer -1)
         (gimp-layer-set-mode CopyLayer ADDITION-MODE)
         (gimp-layer-set-opacity CopyLayer shadowopacity)
         (gimp-image-add-layer img ShadowLayer -1)
         (gimp-desaturate ShadowLayer)
         (gimp-invert ShadowLayer)
         (let* ((CopyMask (car (gimp-layer-create-mask CopyLayer ADD-WHITE-MASK)))
                (ShadowMask (car (gimp-layer-create-mask ShadowLayer ADD-WHITE-MASK)))
                )
           (gimp-layer-add-mask CopyLayer CopyMask)
           (gimp-layer-add-mask ShadowLayer ShadowMask)
           (gimp-selection-all img)
           (gimp-edit-copy ShadowLayer)
           (gimp-floating-sel-anchor (car (gimp-edit-paste CopyMask TRUE)))
           (gimp-floating-sel-anchor (car (gimp-edit-paste ShadowMask TRUE)))
           )
         (gimp-layer-set-mode ShadowLayer OVERLAY-MODE)
         (gimp-layer-set-opacity ShadowLayer shadowopacity)
         (gimp-image-remove-layer img CopyLayer)
         (gimp-drawable-set-name ShadowLayer "Shadow Recovery")
         )
       )
    
    ;smart sharpen from here: http://registry.gimp.org/node/108
    (if(> sharpness 0)
       (begin
         (gimp-image-add-layer img SharpenLayer -1)
         (gimp-selection-all HSVImage)
         (gimp-edit-copy (aref HSVLayer 0))
         (gimp-image-delete HSVImage)
         (gimp-floating-sel-anchor (car (gimp-edit-paste SharpenLayer FALSE)))
         (gimp-layer-set-mode SharpenLayer VALUE-MODE)
         (plug-in-edge TRUE MaskImage (aref MaskLayer 0) 6 1 0)
         (gimp-levels-stretch (aref MaskLayer 0))
         (gimp-image-convert-grayscale MaskImage)
         (plug-in-gauss TRUE MaskImage (aref MaskLayer 0) 6 6 TRUE)
         (let* ((SharpenChannel (car (gimp-layer-create-mask SharpenLayer ADD-WHITE-MASK)))
                )
           (gimp-layer-add-mask SharpenLayer SharpenChannel)
           (gimp-selection-all MaskImage)
           (gimp-edit-copy (aref MaskLayer 0))
           (gimp-floating-sel-anchor (car (gimp-edit-paste SharpenChannel FALSE)))
           (gimp-image-delete MaskImage)
           (plug-in-unsharp-mask TRUE img SharpenLayer 1 sharpness 0)
           (gimp-layer-set-opacity SharpenLayer 80)
           (gimp-layer-set-edit-mask SharpenLayer FALSE)
           )
         (gimp-drawable-set-name SharpenLayer "Sharpen")
         )
       )
    
    ;enhance local contrast
    (if(> localcontrast 0)
       (begin
         (gimp-edit-copy-visible img)
         (set! tmplayer1 (car (gimp-layer-new-from-visible img img "Temp 1")))
         (set! tmplayer2 (car (gimp-layer-new-from-visible img img "Temp 2")))
         (gimp-image-add-layer img tmplayer1 -1)
         (gimp-image-add-layer img tmplayer2 -1)
         (plug-in-unsharp-mask 1 img tmplayer1 60 localcontrast 0)
         (gimp-layer-set-mode tmplayer2 GRAIN-EXTRACT-MODE)
         (gimp-edit-copy-visible img)
         (set! contrastlayer (car (gimp-layer-new-from-visible img img "Local Contrast")))
         (gimp-image-add-layer img contrastlayer -1)
         (gimp-layer-set-mode contrastlayer GRAIN-MERGE-MODE)
         (gimp-image-remove-layer img tmplayer1)
         (gimp-image-remove-layer img tmplayer2)
         )
       )
    
    ;copy visible three times
    (gimp-edit-copy-visible img)
    (set! overlaylayer (car (gimp-layer-new-from-visible img img "Overlay")))
    (set! overlaylayer2 (car (gimp-layer-new-from-visible img img "Overlay2")))
    (set! screenlayer (car (gimp-layer-new-from-visible img img "Screen")))
    
    ;add screen- and overlay- layers
    (gimp-image-add-layer img screenlayer -1)
    (gimp-image-add-layer img overlaylayer -1)
    (gimp-image-add-layer img overlaylayer2 -1)
    
    ;desaturate layers
    (gimp-desaturate screenlayer)
    (gimp-desaturate overlaylayer)  
    (gimp-desaturate overlaylayer2)  
    
    ;set modes 
    (gimp-layer-set-mode screenlayer SCREEN-MODE)
    (gimp-layer-set-mode overlaylayer OVERLAY-MODE)
    (gimp-layer-set-mode overlaylayer2 OVERLAY-MODE)
    (gimp-layer-set-opacity screenlayer screenopacity)
    (gimp-layer-set-opacity overlaylayer overlayopacity)
    (gimp-layer-set-opacity overlaylayer2 overlayopacity)
    
    ;layermask for the screen layer
    (if(= screenmask TRUE)
       (begin
         (set! floatingsel (car (gimp-layer-create-mask screenlayer 5)))
         (gimp-layer-add-mask screenlayer floatingsel)
         (gimp-invert floatingsel)
         )
       )
    
    ;overlay tint
    ;red
    (if(= tint 1)
       (begin
         (gimp-colorize screenlayer   0 25 0)
         (gimp-colorize overlaylayer  0 25 0)
         (gimp-colorize overlaylayer2 0 25 0)
         )
       )
    ;blue
    (if(= tint 2)
       (begin
         (gimp-colorize screenlayer   225 25 0)
         (gimp-colorize overlaylayer  225 25 0)
         (gimp-colorize overlaylayer2 225 25 0)
         )
       )
    
    ; tidy up
    (gimp-image-undo-group-end img)
    (gimp-displays-flush)
    (gimp-context-pop)
    )
  )

(script-fu-register "elsamuko-national-geographic"
                    _"_National Geographic"
                    "Simulating high quality photos.
Latest version can be downloaded from http://registry.gimp.org/node/9592"
                    "elsamuko <elsamuko@web.de>"
                    "elsamuko"
                    "22/09/08"
                    "*"
                    SF-IMAGE       "Input image"           0
                    SF-DRAWABLE    "Input drawable"        0
                    SF-ADJUSTMENT _"Shadow Recover Opacity"   '(60  0  100  1   5 0 0)
                    SF-ADJUSTMENT _"Sharpness"                '(0.5 0    2  0.1 1 1 0)
                    SF-ADJUSTMENT _"Screen Layer Opacity"     '(50  0  100  1   5 0 0)                    
                    SF-ADJUSTMENT _"Overlay Layer Opacity"    '(50  0  100  1   5 0 0)
                    SF-ADJUSTMENT _"Local Contrast"           '(0.4 0    2  0.1 1 1 0)
                    SF-TOGGLE     _"Layer Mask for the Screen Layer" TRUE
                    SF-OPTION     _"Overlay Tint"           '("Neutral"
                                                              "Red"
                                                              "Blue")
                    )

(script-fu-menu-register "elsamuko-national-geographic" _"<Image>/Filters/Generic")
```

events.target_title: Thumbnailing images (and others) in Nautilus is dog slow

note.body:
I have the same issue on Debian testing with nautilus 3.30.5. Nemo 3.8.5 (a nautilus fork) is able to generate the thumbnails much faster.

While I have been experimenting with a custom thumbnailer I noticed that the thumbnailer call by nautilus was `custom_thumbnailer /tmp/gnome-desktop-file-to-thumbnail.cpp /tmp/gnome-desktop-thumbnailer.png 256`, which looks like nautilus makes *copies* of the files for which it is generating thumbnails. Maybe this explains the slow thumbnail generation of nautilus?

As a side note, my custom thumbnailer works perfectly fine with nemo 3.8.5 and nautilus 3.22.3, but not with nautilus 3.30.5 for some reason. In general I think these problems are caused by some (relatively) recent changes to the way that nautilus generates thumbnails.

events.target_title: Thumbnailing images (and others) in Nautilus is dog slow

note.body:
I have the libgnome-desktop-3-17 package installed on my system, which is version 3.30.2-4 of the gnome-desktop library and very close to the most recent version afaik. Since this is the only version of the library I have installed both nemo and nautilus should use it

I built nemo 4.0.6 from source (release build) and here is the time it takes generating all thumbnails when opening a folder with 363 image files of a total size of 405MB.

|        | Time | Disk write |
| ------ | ------ | -------- |
| nemo 3.8.5 | 11s | 1200 K/s |
| nemo 4.0.6 | 22s | 1800 K/s |
| nautilus 3.30.5 | 55s | 400 K/s |

The third column is the approximate disk write activity as reported by iotop during thumbnail generation. This does not look like any of the three file managers is copying image files, although I still don't understand why the input file in the thumbnailer call with nautilus seems to be /tmp/gnome-desktop-file-to-thumbnail.cpp. Maybe it's just a symlink?

Not sure if this is related to the original problem of the slow thumbnailing, but here is how I actually found out about the thumbnailer call: When nautilus tries to create a thumbnail with my own thumbnailer, the thumbnailer appears to be run in the gnome system monitor at max CPU indefinitely (which is strange since this is the very same thumbnailer that works perfectly fine with nautilus 3.22.3 and both versions of nemo). So I simply copied the command from the thumbnailer process in the system monitor.

Debugging the thumbnailing with strace turned out to be difficult, because then Nautilus all of a sudden fails generating all thumbnails (also for image files like png).

Edit: I changed my thumbnailer's main function to output the calling command to a log file before anything else happens. Both nemo 3.8.5 and nemo 4.0.6 pass the full path of the original file for which a thumbnail should be generated to the thumbnailer. With nautilus 3.30.5 nothing is written to the log file, although this is the first thing that is done in the main function. The system monitor still claims that the thumbnailer is run.

I modified the gdk-pixbuf-thumbnailer to output the thumbnailer command to a terminal when thumbnailing png images and this is the result:

Nautilus 3.30.5: `/usr/bin/gdk-pixbuf-thumbnailer -s 256 file:///tmp/gnome-desktop-file-to-thumbnail.png /tmp/gnome-desktop-thumbnailer.png`

events.target_title: Thumbnailing images (and others) in Nautilus is dog slow

note.body:
There is nothing magical going on with your machine, I see the same performance difference between nautilus and thunar and I do agree with you that gdk-pixbuf-thumbnailer is probably the main reason for the slow thumbnailing. (Btw on my machine thunar generates smaller thumbnails than nautilus, which may also be a part of the explanation.)

However, since both nautilus and nemo use gdk-pixbuf it seems to me that the performance difference I observed is caused by nautilus directly.

No the airplane mode is enabled through suspending (I assume, correct me if I'm wrong). The sequence would go like this:
* WiFi is connected, everything is normal
* Laptop lid is closed, putting computer into standby
* Laptop lid opened, bringing computer to login screen
* Airplane mode is automatically disabled and WiFi begins to reconnect
* If reconnecting is interrupted by user login, airplane mode is enabled. (I'm assuming this is because somewhere the state of the network connection is being checked, and the most recent status was airplane mode during standby)
* If instead of logging in as quickly as possible, I wait until the WiFi connection is re-established, then I can log in and the WiFi is connected, as expected.

events.target_title: Make mouse speed incremental
Make mouse speed incremental

note.body:
@whot That's sounds like something a KDE user would say. :D This is currently one of the most unrestrictive things on Gnome.

I'm not so sure it's that restrictive:
*  This is how it has been on Windows since forever and "no-one" has complained.
*  There's no actual visual representation of your current value, so you can't really know your ideal value.
*  And even if you did, there's no way input that value to a new computer / installation. You're favorite setting is lost forever. (Without a terminal). 

Some additional thoughts:
*  This might seem like a weird suggestion to those that use track pad. It probably doesn't really matter at that space tbh.
*  Using a mouse with 'flat' profile is where this matters the most: you can instantly feel whenever your mouse speed isn't one of those values I listed: you lose that raw feeling and there's additional input lag. This makes the current setup very unattractive to any potential gamers and others with a good mouse setup.

events.target_title: Make mouse speed incremental

note.body:
There's always an option of hybrid model, where those values would be "sticky", but you could still choose anything from between. Or pressing a button could "unlock" linear mode. Or at least there should be a way to input values manually. Currently there's not even a way to go back to default setting.

Ok, so:
*  Pointer speed set to 0: 1 registered pixel from mouse makes the cursor move 1 pixel.
*  Pointer speed set to -0.5: every other registered pixel is basically disregarded.
*  Pointer speed set to -0.583636262: every... Nth registered pixel is disregarded. This time it has to somehow try and extrapolate which pixels it should disregard. So there's obviously additional input lag and it just feels weird.

events.target_title: Make mouse speed incremental

note.body: Ok. Well, anyways, you can definitely feel that something's "off" even if it's technically not input lag.

note.body:
Hi, I was also facing the same issue with Nautilus and MPV, so I created a temporary solution for this issue, until the bug will be fixed. Steps to take:
1.  Create bash script and put it in some directory. I named it `mpv.sh` and created it inside `~/.config/mpv/` directory. Don't forget to make it executable with `chmod +x mpv.sh`.
2.  In the newly created bash script write this code and save the file:
```bash
#!/bin/bash

echo "$1" >> ~/.config/mpv/playlist.m3u

# Check if another instance of script is running
pidof -o %PPID -x $0 >/dev/null && echo "ERROR: Script $0 already running" && exit 1

mpv ~/.config/mpv/playlist.m3u && rm ~/.config/mpv/playlist.m3u
```
3.  Go to `/usr/share/applications` and search for `mpv.desktop`. Edit this file requires sudo.
4.  In `mpv.desktop` replace `Exec=mpv --player-operation-mode=pseudo-gui -- %U` with `Exec=~/.config/mpv/mpv.sh` and save the file.

That's it. Now you can play multiple files with only one MPV instance. What the script does is that it basically creates temporary playlist and executes it with MPV. When MPV is closed, playlist is destroyed.

note.body:
I have been running this all day, and I did find one problem, which showed up on both Caja and Nemo but did not show up on Nautilus (which seems to force right-click menus to a smaller range of sizes): 

If the right-click menu for one of the icons in a folder (desktop, navigation, whatever) is opened one one kind of file, then opened on another, different kind, the menu needs to be resized as its contents have changed. With this PR applied the menus now show scrollbars if the size of the screen constrains them, but also show scrollbars if the same menu was previously opened with a shorter list of menuitems. In the converse case extra space is left.

Worse, this is also true in the horizontal direction, causing contents to be truncated if the second or subsequent opening loads wider menuitems.

For some reason the window dimensions are not getting resized when the menu itself is rebuilt.

events.target_title: Fix submenu size

note.body:
I ran this most of the afternoon on Feb 6, and noticed one problem: when the same popup menu was opened more than once but with a different set of menuitems it did not get resized with some applications. Nautilus was OK but Caja and Nemo both exhibited the right-click menus on icons staying for the entire run of the program at whatever size they were first opened.

Scrollbars now appear if the size of the screen constrains a menu, but if a menu is closed and reopened with a longer list of menuitems that too now shows scrollbars and the menu is shown at its original size.

This also happens in the horizontal direction, and since we don't use scrollbars there, if a longer menuitem is loaded on a second or subsequent opening of a menu it gets truncated.

My guess is we need to ensure that the menu is resized everytime it is popped up, or ideally every time it is popped up after having been altered (so as to avoid the calculation when the menu has not been changed).

quick selection tool
quick selection tool

note.body:
Here is my understanding of the quick selection tool.

![def](/uploads/1378c9c20063e73eaee0c642cf4691fa/def.png)

The overall segmentation problem is seen as a max-flow graph cut problem. The paper "Paint Selection" the algorithm is divided in three parts:
1.  Paint Selection using progressive selection only
2.  Progressive selection + dual-core graphcut
3.  Progressive selection + dual-core graphcut + adaptive band upsampling

Let's start with Progressive labeling:
Given the existing selection F and current brush B, the progressive selection computes a new selection F′ in the background U , as shown in Figure. Once the new selection F′ is obtained, the existing selection is updated as F = F ∪ F′ for the next user interaction. 

In each triggered optimization, we first estimate the foreground color information. We denote the intersection between the brush B and the background U as seed pixels S (S = B ∩ U). To obtain a stable estimation, we compute a box R by dilating the bounding box of the region S by a certain width (typically 40 pixels). We denote the intersection between the dilated box R and the existing selection F as local foreground pixels L (L = R ∩ F ), as shown in Figure. Using both seed pixels and local foreground pixels, we build a local foreground color model p^f(·) by fitting a Gaussian Mixture Model (GMM) with four components. Using local foreground pixels makes the estimation more stable be- cause the brush or seed pixel region may be very small.

Then, we update the background color model. At the very beginning of the user interaction, a background color model p^b(·) (a GMM with eight components) is initialized by randomly sampling a number (typically 1,200) of pixels from the background. In each subsequent user interaction, we replace the samples that were labeled as foreground in the previous interaction with the same number of pixels randomly sampled from the background. The background GMM is reestimated using the updated samples. 

With the two color models, we apply a multilevel graph-cut-based optimization, to obtain an expanded new selection.

The binary labels X = {xp} of the image are obtained by minimizing an energy E(x). The smoothness part of the energy function remain pretty same as given in the [GrabCut](https://cvg.ethz.ch/teaching/cvl/2012/grabcut-siggraph04.pdf) with a very little change. The data term is changed in Paint selection according to the need (given in equation 1 in the paper).

If we look at the code of [GrabCut](https://github.com/opencv/opencv/blob/master/modules/imgproc/src/grabcut.cpp) we find it very much similar to the Paint selection. GrabCut utilizes GMM with 5 components count (in Paint selection we require 4 for foreground and 8 for background). The smoothness function *calcNWeights()* and calculation of beta in  *calcBeta()* need to be changed a little bit. The only thing then left will be updating the data term. With that the first part of the paint selection would be completed. 

I was wondering if anyone here is interested in implementing this feature with me? I could certainly use some help.

note.body:
Ah, yes, I completely forgot about the report.

Yes, it's a crash bug in the latest libxml2 release. It's also data
dependent, which makes it even worse. The crash is reproducible by first
parsing this snippet:

"""
<!DOCTYPE data [
<!ENTITY a "a">
<!ENTITY b "&a;">
]>
<data>&b;</data>
"""

and then taking the "data" root node and appending it to another XML tree
using xmlAddChild().

events.target_title: Uninitialized memory access in xmlSAX2TextNode

note.body:
I would argue that the current guard (`ctxt->dictNames`) that is used in `xmlSAX2TextNode()` is the wrong one. It should really use `!ctxt->html` instead. The fact that `ctxt->dictNames` is disabled when parsing HTML is a decision that can be changed, not a law of nature, which makes this code at least fragile.

I also think that it should not guard the XML_PARSE_COMPACT code – because, what's the relation?

Here is a patch that
1) moves the compact parsing code out of the guard and
2) adds `!ctxt->html` to guard the two look-ahead tests, which are not valid in the HTML parser.

[html_look_ahead_fix.patch](/uploads/266bf7363ad98565089f3fa52c30ed87/html_look_ahead_fix.patch)

While 1 week is a tiny exaggeration, 1/2 a week is over optimistic on most of my machines. It also is not only about the time when it happens to work, but the chance of it working is tiny. The rust compiler, it's millions of dependency crates and the rust build system are broken one way or another basically every time you try to build on a less common architecture.

This means that Rust, at this point in time, is a very very bad choice of implementation language for any library used by lots of other things (that do not by themselves require rust). It is like writing all hash functions for a standard C++ class library in Modula 2.

It is your choice, of course, but it is not only heavyweight but most of the time a real show stopper. Just an hour ago  my Pinebook (aarch64) failed to build rust as dependency for librsvg, so I will switch back to the old C version there.

events.target_title: Clipboard transparency lost when copying and pasting from GIMP to another application

note.body:
As issue https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gimp/issues/1532 says, the main cause of this is indeed that Chrome uses DIB as image transfer method, and abuses the 32-bit RGB-specced format as if it were ARGB.

Strangely, for pasting images *into* Chrome, it does not seem to read DIBv5 as clipboard image source at all, meaning the only alpha-capable image input it accepts is that ugly classic DIB abused as ARGB format.

This means that the best overall solution is to always put DIB on the clipboard as if it were 32-bit ARGB, meaning, for images without alpha, the padding bytes should be cleared to FF, and for those with alpha, the alpha should be put into the 'padding' bytes anyway. It's dirty, but it's still perfectly valid according to the specs.

Pasting into GIMP *from* Chrome clipboard is a lot trickier, of course... as I detailed in my response to the other issue.

events.target_title: Pasted png images from external applications lose alpha information

note.body:
@asmodis DIB specs don't mention that header. That's only for BMP *files*, not for DIB *data*.

But, it does look like Chrome abuses DIB as being ARGB, yes.

In fact, while Chrome also puts the data on the clipboard in DIBv5 (Format17) format, which is alpha-capable, and uses BI_BITFIELDS (0x03) as set 'compression' type, it does not seem to set the alpha channel's bitfield in the header, making the image still officially RGB.

The format in general seems quite messy. In BI_BITFIELDS mode it has masks for the RGB colour components both in its header and behind the header, as per [the BITMAPINFO specs](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-gb/windows/desktop/api/wingdi/ns-wingdi-tagbitmapinfo), and I haven't found anything specifying which of these two is actually used. And alpha seems to be a rather fuzzy thing too; nothing in [the specs](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/desktop/api/wingdi/ns-wingdi-bitmapv5header) really says how/when/if the alpha mask from the v5 header is used.

events.target_title: Painting on indexed images by index

note.body:
IIRC, painting on indexed images used to always revert to no AA pure colour in order versions. If you use smooth painting, then sure, it should just take the closest match. I don't think the tradeoff of being able to use such things in indexed mode was worth it.

The current implementation of indexed graphics has some serious issues in general. I've encountered ridiculous slowdowns when opening indexed images and when pasting on them, and, when you add a second layer by dragging and dropping a second indexed image into it, it plain ignores the fact it's supposed to be limited to the one palette. Anything painted on that added layer will adapt to *that* image's palette, without you even being able to see or edit that palette.

events.target_title: Internal links inside emails don't work

note.body:
Thanks for continuous instructions. I've repaired the bug I guess...At least it works fine on my computer...The approach is as follows.

Signal Part
---
First in the `conversation-web-view.js`, I added a function called `getAnchorTargetY()` to get the Y coordinate for the element anchor targeting at.

Then in the `conversation-web-view`, I added a adapter function `get_anchor_target_y()`.

In the `conversation-message`, I first added a function `on_link_activated()` to replace the direct connect, and used it to decide if a link is internal link by looking if it contains "geary:body#".
And connect both right-click action and click signal to it.

In the `conversation-email`, the signal from the `conversation-message` will be passed on to the internal class called `EmailRow` of the `conversation-list-box`, but when signal comes out from the `EmailRow` it will attach a reference to the `EmailRow` instance so that the `conversation-box-list` know which email to scroll to.

Scrolling Part
--- 
To do the scrolling properly, we need a few more dimensions than the anchor's y coordinates.
First is the message's summary height. In order to get that, I added two function with the same name `get_summary_height` in both `conversation-message` and `conversation-email`(In the email class I only get out the primary message...), then call the function from the `conversation-box-list`.

In order to calculate the scroll part, I added a helper function as follows.
![2019-02-09-181010_800x356_scrot](/uploads/257c2a93104a6ec7221d0f0093e45aa8/2019-02-09-181010_800x356_scrot.png)

I (just like @eric1 ) humbly beg you to reconsider this change. I never knew the transparent effect was considered a problem.
While the reasons you have stated do seem logical, I can't seem to be able to reproduce the issue, as no matter what background I set, the text is always visible and readable even on my old LCD panel under direct sunlight.

note.body:
While I understand the corner cases that could lead to issues and the burden to add some new gsettings, considering there is already some nice work done in @verdre branch to polish the UX of the top panel it seems to me that it would make sense to:
 
1. Try to merge the polish this cycle as the proposed merge is definitely an improvement in all cases.
2. In case merging in time is not possible, revert the current changes to the top bar and get the polish merged during the next cycle to avoid visual regressions and a "transparent -> black -> polished transparent" scenario for the next releases.

It's a bit sad that we had to trough to all this drama to get the top bar UX rare corner cases solved and IMHO, now that we have momentum to get it closed properly, we should try to keep it and avoid visual regression.

As a distro dev, I can totally support this happening even if it is behind a compile-time option and is disabled by default. In fact, I'd expect gnome-software to pull metrics from all active repos, but I'm unsure if the repos provide this data.

Instead of prioritizing one data source over the other, they should be aggregated. Where they agree, you know for sure that the app is popular. If not, prioritize the repo with more installed apps. If that is equal, prioritize the repo alphabetically/install date/whatever other way. For instance:

If repo A (10 apps installed) says org.gnome.Builder is the #5 app, and repo B (3 apps installed) says that org.gnome.Builder is #1, then you know builder is popular. If A says gedit is #7 and music isn't on the list, and B says gedit isn't on the list and music is #7, prioritize A's data. I hope you get the idea of what I'm going for

events.target_title: Disabling Mark as Read Automatically
Don't automatically select 1st newly arrived message
Don't automatically select 1st newly arrived message

note.body: Good point.  Unselecting the "Automatically select next message" preference in fact changes the behavior.  However, I would still suggest the behavior to be changed to match more closely the behavior observed in other email clients, as the "Automatically select next message" is really handy.  Example: Apple Mail on macOS.  It does not have a setting to not mark messages as read, it will advance to the next message, meaning mimic the behavior of "Automatically select next message" as in Geary.  But when left with an empty Inbox folder, the focus will remain on Inbox in the Mailbox aka Folder list when a new message arrives.  I think that behavior to be correct compared to Geary with or without the "Automatically select next message" be enabled.  Changing this however I would not see as a high priority.

events.target_title: Don't automatically select 1st newly arrived message

note.body: If there would be a preference as we discussed in #204, which would allow for a behavior to only mark messages as read when an action is taken on them, then you are correct, the message would not be marked as read when it is automatically selected.  However, and that is why I specifically made the headline of this issue "don't automatically select 1st newly arrived message", it would only mask the issue.  In other words, regardless of such a preference as outlined in #204, Geary should simply not automatically select the 1st newly arrived message automatically in any circumstance.  That includes, that Geary should not automatically select the 1st newly arrived message with the "Automatically select next message" preference enabled.  I am going back to the Apple Mail client on macOS, that I had quoted in my earlier comment, as well as Apple Mail on iOS for that matter.  Both do mark messages as read the moment you select them, in fact they don't even have a feature to disable the marking as read, but neither does automatically select a newly arrived message when left in a state where the focus is on the folder list or in case of iOS on the conversation list. Also leaving the Gmail web client open on the inbox does not automatically select the 1st newly arrived message.  I continue to think that the current behavior in Geary is simply not intuitive and the behavior observed in other mail clients is more correct, and hence aligning with that commonly expected behavior is preferable.
